title: Topophiles: Swiss maps serif font
content:
I like the letter g very much, but what is it?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209213018im_/http:/typophile.com/files/jungfrau_3493.png)
author: Jan Zurawski

comments.content: Interesting. That kind of "ear" usually appears in "more than bold" Bodonis.

Cześć Jan,  
this is one of those special typefaces for cartography. They used to have pretty generic names, like ‘Kartenschrift’ [map type]. Hard to find samples.  
Your best option might be [Römisch Stehend](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209213018/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/linotype/roemisch_com_stehend/?&sample_text=Jungfrau&sample_size=74&update=0). Karten-Augustea is also very close, but it seems to be unavailable.

By the way, you might enjoy [this g](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209213018/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/hardwig/2524903281/) aswell.  
F

Hallo Florian!  
Thank you very much.  
I found this thread helpfull: [www.typophile.com/node/54634](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209213018/http:/www.typophile.com/node/54634 "www.typophile.com/node/54634")  
Berthold's Karten-Augustea could be [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209213018/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/59825996@N00/3110505654/)  
Also Uli tips off forgery of Karten-Augustea, so the font was digitised (by Berthold?).

This hand-made "Ausgang." is beautifull!

Regards  
Jan Żurawski

Solved. Though I think the font employed in Bundesamt fur Landestopographie 3084 Wabern looks a bit different than Karten-Augustea. We need to look at Berthold's fotosatz specimen. Is there anybody here?

Regards - Jan Żurawski
